docs.lead_paragraph: HARVARD'S FITNESS OUTLINE FITNESSBy Jane Ogle What are the basic fitness requirements needed to keep a man at his peak? And, with time at such a premium, what has priority? The answers to these key questions were outlined at a recent seminar on nutrition and fitness at the Harvard Club of New York City. The session was coordinated by Dr. Jose Luis Barbosa-Saldivar, endocrinologist, nutritionist and associate in clinical medicine at Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons. Among the panelists were Dr. W. Virgil Brown, professor and director of the division of atherosclerosis and metabolism at Mount Sinai School of Medicine; Dr. Sami Hashim, director of the division of metabolism and nutrition at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center and professor of nutrition at Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons; Dr. George Sheehan, cardiologist, medical editor of Runner's World and a member of the stress-testing laboratory at Riverview Hospital in Red Bank, N.J., and Michael O'Shea, director of the Sports Training Institute in New York. The program these experts recommend is set forth here in the form of a classic Harvard outline. I. NUTRITION GUIDELINES

headline.main: THE GUIDE TO NEW YORK COOKING SCHOOLS: WHERE TO LOOK TO LEARN WHICH CUISINE

docs.lead_paragraph: The cooking schools on these pages were reviewed by Florence Fabricant and Moira Hodgson. This article was written by Mrs. Fabricant. DURING the last few years cooking schools around the city have been changing. An increasingly sophisticated level of student is enrolling for classes and, along with this, the quality of teaching has improved and the kitchens have become handsomer and better equipped. Most instructors now have assistants to handle cleanup as well as some of the more routine aspects of preparation. Students can expect to receive detailed printed recipes. In short, the schools are becoming more professional. There are now a few larger schools, such as the New School's new headquarters on 34th Street and the Culinary Center in Greenwich Village, that offer a full catalogue of courses - ranging from the fundamentals of using a knife to highly specialized Japanese noodle-making techniques.
